intro: Ornithogalum monspeliense, commonly known as the mountain onion, is a bulbous perennial plant native to southern Africa. It features a tall, slender stem with narrow, grass-like leaves and produces clusters of white or pale yellow flowers. The plant belongs to the Asparagaceae family and is characterized by its underground bulb, which stores nutrients for growth. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Due to its ornamental value, it is cultivated in gardens, though it can be invasive in some regions.
